Functional Statement: Alters water quantity and quality via land uses.
Attenuates upstream flows via natural and artificial features (e.g., wetlands).
Addresses localized inputs from tributaries, ditches, and pipes.
Integrates the range of “typical” flows experienced by other processes.
Examines the degree to which upstream infrastructure or land uses have fundamentally altered flow regimes (e.g., hydropeaking, dams, withdrawals).
Ensures habitat availability and water quality during low water levels.
Indicates non-storm conditions experienced the majority of the time.
Influences erosion and channel maintenance during peak flows.
Enhances nutrient cycling and habitat availability via water exchange.
Addresses surface-subsurface connections important for temperature regulation, nutrient dynamics, and food webs.
Addresses legacy, ongoing, and anticipated change in channel form (i.e., dimension) and slope (i.e., profile) in response to flow and sediment inputs.
Examines the role of bank processes and erosion in channel change.
Observes patterns in sinuosity and curvature affecting habitat complexity.
Maintains channel morphology and habitats through sediment processes.
Enhances habitat complexity and streambank stability.
Supports aquatic habitats through streambed material and bedform dynamics.
Regulates water chemistry, drives carbon sources and dynamics, and governs the breadth of niche space available for organisms.
Dictates availability of energy sources and supports food webs with ties to pH, production, respiration, and overall system metabolism.
Drives productivity and quality of waters based on nitrogen & phosphorous.
Indicates the fate and transport of contaminants and other focal constituents.
Supports diverse niches for a range of life stages of aquatic & riparian taxa.
Provides for reproduction, survival, and movement of key taxa.
Facilitates balanced assemblages composed of native taxa with minimal invasive species dominance and representation of keystone species, ecological engineers, and other functionally important taxa.
Facilitates colonization dynamics and capacity to recover after disturbance.
